title: US regulators worry vape manufacturers are using bots to spread propaganda about e-cigarettes
text:
Government regulators are worried about how e-cigarette manufacturers are marketing their products.

This week both the House Energy and Commerce Committee and the Massachusetts attorney general's office asked five major vape manufacturers whether they used bots to spread marketing materials about their products on social media.

In recent months, politicians have helped stoke fears about the potential dangers of e-cigarettes after a report from the CDC attributed 26 deaths in the US to the use of e-cigarettes.

A recent study looked at 1.2 million vape-related Twitter posts and found 77 percent came from bots.

Earlier this month, the Federal Trade Commission ordered major e-cigarette manufacturers to submit detailed information about their marketing budgets to evaluate whether they were using potentially deceptive practices on social media.

One recent study, analysed a sample of 1.2 million Twitter posts about e-cigarettes or tobacco and found that almost 80 percent came from bots.

'No one pays attention to these bots. They exist in their own corner of the internet, they're very cheap to unleash, but no one pays attention to them,' Greg Conley, of the American Vaping Association told the Wall Street Journal.

Additional vaping deaths have now been confirmed in Texas, Utah and Massachusetts, bringing the national toll to 28 fatalities across 23 states (red) in the US

Bots are everywhere on the Internet. A recent study found that posts could be bought from shadow social media companies for as little as $8 each.

Another company would sell bundles of 10 social media posts for $100, each from unique accounts.

With the US e-cigarette market estimated to grow to more than $47 billion by 2025, there's plenty of incentive for manufacturers to press every advantage they can to get an edge.
description: US regulators are worried about the popularity of e-cigarettes and have begun demanding major vape manufacturers share their marketing budgets to make sure they're not using bots.
